newsitem.title: UK: Europe, Mideast LPG stay strong despite U.S. fall.
newsitem.headline: Europe, Mideast LPG stay strong despite U.S. fall.

text.p: European liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) prices weathered a bearish storm which swept U.S. propane and crude markets on Thursday on strong local demand and rising prices in the Middle East, traders said.
"Belvieu came off yesterday but LPG in Europe is still very strong," a trader said.
Propane cargoes gained $10 over the week to trade at $277.00-$278.50 cif northern Europe, and several companies were still short for November.
The North Sea was buoyed by demand from local consumers and also requirements in the Mediterranean and Latin America, particularly Brazil.

"Prices in the Middle East are very high and we see some players in the Mediterranean and Latin America looking for alternative sources," a North Sea producer said. Algeria offered $300 cif for a propane cargo requirement in Lavera, southern France.
Butane, which has lagged propane over the past two weeks, surged by about $25 to talk around $260 cif NWE, dealers said.
One major North Sea producer said the BP posted price of $232 for butane was much too low, being based on a deal two weeks before at $244 cif.
